message: hi guys
I'm done with the Pragmatic Programmer book on iPhone Dev. What book should I read next, especially if I want to get more into game development?
Absolute best book out there: http://www.amazon.com/iPhone-App-Development-Missing-Manual/dp/0596809778

i got a question, i am from mongolia and bought a iphone 3g but it does not work in here. by the way i heard that i need jealbreak or somethig i should unlock it. do you guys have a experience related with this thing? thnks

You might want to open a Safari Books account and peruse some of the cocos2d game programming books available there. I thought "Learn  iPhone and iPad cocos2d Game Development" was pretty good. Also, consider diving into OpenGL specifically. "iPhone 3D Programming" seems ok but it's mostly C++ based.
@batbayar Just search on Google "Jailbreak iphone 3g". There are a lot of solutions to list here. Most of the sites will provide instructions how to do it.
@stephan I figured as much. At my last job I did some simple iPhone development for a test app they were considering, but I don't have a mac myself
I started reading this one (http://oreilly.com/catalog/9781449302672/), didn't expect much but its actually a very good book with a lot of details I didn't know yet
for example, I didn't know that when you declare a @property you can leave off the instance variable declaration
@stephan How practical is iPhone dev without a Mac
@loganfrederick not at all, I'm afraid. You'd need Apple's tools which are only available for mac
but you can get the cheapest MAc available, its still good enough for development
at our company we bought a couple of iMacs which we share out temporarly to the people that have iOS projects
@barce really should find some good content for OpenGL
You could use a hackintosh
@chrisnet, thnk you...
yw
( not a book but covers some solid ground )
There is an advanced iOS class from Madison Tech on iTunes U. That was pretty good.
+1 @mbuckbee I just have OS X installed on my laptop next to Windows
do you guys think you should skip the beginners books even with lots of (other) programming experience?
@d_druska Not really, there are some peculiarities with building in xcode and using interface builder that are easily explained by themselves in the early books.
You don't need to spend a lot of time in them
Just run through the examples, make sure they build and you can move on to bigger things
cool, thanks for the suggestion @nickoneill
